Award.AwardTitle: 2014 Pingree Park Dynamical Systems School: Foundations and Frontiers of Symbolic Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "2014 Pingree Park Dynamical Systems School: Foundations and Frontiers of Symbolic Dynamics" held at Colorado State University on the dates of July 13-18, 2014. This conference, which is an extension of dynamical systems conferences given at the same site during the summers of 2008-2011, is dedicated to the study of classical and multidimensional symbolic dynamics. A particular area of focus will be on recent developments in active study of Z^d-symbolic dynamics. Three mini-courses are planned to give graduate students and junior faculty an opportunity to learn foundational material in the subject, as well as to learn of important recent developments. Plenary lectures are also to be given.

Symbolic dynamics is part of the mathematical subject known as dynamical systems. In addition to its significance in mathematics, symbolic dynamics has applications in computer science and other subjects involving time evolution through discrete time steps. The meeting provides an excellent opportunity for students and junior researchers to learn about the state of the art in this field, to interact with experts in the topic area, and to develop research collaborations. It is planned that there will be thirty-six participants, of which a significant number will be junior faculty. Particular emphasis is given to recruiting women and members of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from NSF were used to support the 2014 Pingree Park Dynamical Systems Workshop: Foundations and Frontiers in Symbolic Dynamics.

The focus of the meeting was symbolic dynamical systems. Generally speaking, a "dynamical system" for a mathematician is a set of points along with a rule that governs how the set of points evolves over time. Symbolic systems form an extremely interesting subclass of dynamical systems, and are also useful in studying more general systems. For instance, in any dynamical system, if one breaks the space into finitely many pieces and then tracks the sequence of which pieces a point visits throughout its orbit, the set of such sequences comprises a symbolic system, which can be used to recover much of the information about the original system. Symbolic dynamics has connections to several mathematical areas outside of dynamics, such as combinatorics and linear algebra, and to topics in other sciences, such as information theory, coding theory, and statistical physics.

This meeting brought together 33 researchers working in different parts of this flourishing field. The main goals were to 1) foster the development of young researchers in the field 2) gather researchers from closely related fields to communicate results and stimulate new research. The workshop featured mini-courses delivered by top-notch researchers - Brian Marcus (Univ. British Columbia), Karl Petersen (Univ. North Carolina) and Dan Thompson (Ohio State Univ.). In addition to these mini-courses, conference participants presented 16 additional talks, and there was a group discussion on open problems in the area. Two of the problems have been subsequently solved, mostly due to discussions that took place at the meeting. Funds from the NSF were used to sponsor the visits of participants at the meeting, e.g., travel, meals & lodging.

The Pingree Park Campus of Colorado State University is a somewhat remote facility in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado which provides an ideal setting for working on abstract mathematical problems. These kinds of meetings remain essential for making progress in the field because they bring a substantial number of people together for face-to-face communication.

As in all fields within pure mathematics the goal is to work to solve abstract mathematical problems. This meeting provided participants an opportunity to learn from others and to share their results and their perspectives on unsolved problems. Bringing together these alternate perspectives is typically a key ingredient to producing new results in mathematics. We were pleased to be able to attract leaders in the field from around the world, as well as several beginning scholars. During this meeting, talks were scheduled from late morning to early evening. Talks gave researchers the opportunity to report on new results and for audience members to question the speaker about their techniques. Early mornings were reserved for more open ended discussions, allowing researchers working on very closely related problems to exchange ideas and collaborate toward solving problems. Several collaborative groups were able to use the meeting as an opportunity to get together and advance their projects. 

Altogether this successful meeting which furthered the understanding of dynamical systems.
